Detail from [frontispiece](/wiki/Book_frontispiece "Book frontispiece") to
Thomas Wilson's Correct Method of German and French Waltzing (1816), showing
nine positions of the Waltz, clockwise from the left (the musicians are at far
left). At that time, the waltz was a relatively new dance in England, and the
fact that it was a couples dance (as opposed to the traditional group dances),
and that the gentleman clasped his arm around the lady's waist, gave it a
dubious moral status in the eyes of some.

The **waltz** (from German:
["Walzer"](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walzer_\(Tanz\) "de:Walzer \(Tanz\)")
pronounced [[ˈvalt͡sɐ̯]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Standard_German "Help:IPA/Standard
German")) is a [ballroom](/wiki/Ballroom_dance "Ballroom dance") and [folk
dance](/wiki/Folk_dance "Folk dance"), normally in [![About this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:3-4_rhythm_metre_meter_time_measure.ogg
"About this sound")
[triple](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6f/3-4_rhythm_metre_meter_time_measure.ogg
"3-4 rhythm metre meter time measure.ogg") ([help](/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help
"Wikipedia:Media
help")·[info](/wiki/File:3-4_rhythm_metre_meter_time_measure.ogg "File:3-4
rhythm metre meter time measure.ogg")) [time](/wiki/Time_signature "Time
signature"), performed primarily in [closed position](/wiki/Closed_position
"Closed position").

Waltz

There are several references to a sliding or gliding dance that would evolve
into the **waltz** that date from 16th century Europe, including the
representations of the [printmaker](/wiki/Printer_\(publishing\) "Printer
\(publishing\)") [Hans Sebald Beham](/wiki/Sebald_Beham "Sebald Beham"). The
French philosopher [Montaigne](/wiki/Montaigne "Montaigne") wrote of a dance
he saw in 1580 in [Augsburg](/wiki/Augsburg "Augsburg"), where the dancers
held each other so closely that their faces touched. Kunz Haas (of
approximately the same period) wrote, "Now they are dancing the godless
_Weller_ or _Spinner_ ".[1] "The vigorous peasant dancer, following an
instinctive knowledge of the weight of fall, utilises his surplus energy to
press all his strength into the proper beat of the bar, thus intensifying his
personal enjoyment in dancing".[2]

The peasants of Bavaria, Tyrol, and Styria began dancing a dance called
Walzer, a dance for couples, around 1750. The [Ländler](/wiki/L%C3%A4ndler
"Ländler"), also known as the Schleifer, a country dance in **3**  
**4** time, was popular in [Bohemia](/wiki/Bohemia "Bohemia"),
[Austria](/wiki/Austria "Austria"), and [Bavaria](/wiki/Bavaria "Bavaria"),
and spread from the countryside to the suburbs of the city. While the
eighteenth century upper classes continued to dance the [minuet](/wiki/Minuet
"Minuet"), bored noblemen slipped away to the balls of their servants.[3]

In the 1771 German novel _Geschichte des Fräuleins von Sternheim_ by [Sophie
von La Roche](/wiki/Sophie_von_La_Roche "Sophie von La Roche"), a high-minded
character complains about the newly introduced waltz among aristocrats thus:
"But when he put his arm around her, pressed her to his breast, cavorted with
her in the shameless, indecent whirling-dance of the Germans and engaged in a
familiarity that broke all the bounds of good breeding—then my silent misery
turned into burning rage."[4]

Describing life in Vienna (dated at either 1776 or 1786[5]), Don Curzio wrote,
"The people were dancing mad ... The ladies of Vienna are particularly
celebrated for their grace and movements of waltzing of which they never
tire." There is a waltz in the second act finale of the opera "Una Cosa Rara"
written by [Martin y Soler](/wiki/Martin_y_Soler "Martin y Soler") in 1786.
Soler's waltz was marked Andante con moto, or "at a walking pace with motion",
but the flow of the dance was sped-up in Vienna leading to the
Geschwindwalzer, and the Galloppwalzer.[6][7]

In the transition from country to town, the hopping of the Ländler, a dance
known as Langaus, became a sliding step, and gliding rotation replaced
stamping rotation.[5]

In the 19th century, the word primarily indicated that the dance was a turning
one; one would "waltz" in the [polka](/wiki/Polka "Polka") to indicate
rotating rather than going straight forward without turning.

The Viennese custom is to slightly anticipate the second beat of each bar,
making it sound as if the third is late and creating a certain buoyancy. The
younger Strauss ([Johann Strauss II](/wiki/Johann_Strauss_II "Johann Strauss
II")) would sometimes break up the one-two-three of the melody with a one-two
pattern in the accompaniment along with other rhythms, maintaining the **3**  
**4** time while causing the dancers to dance a two-step waltz. The metronome
speed for a full bar varies between 60 and 70, with the waltzes of the first
Strauss ([Johann Strauss I](/wiki/Johann_Strauss_I "Johann Strauss I")) often
played faster than those of his sons.[8]

Shocking many when it was first introduced,[9] the waltz became fashionable in
[Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna") around the 1780s, spreading to many other
countries in the years to follow. According to contemporary singer Michael
Kelly, it reached England in 1791,.[10] During the Napoleonic Wars, infantry
soldiers of the King's German Legion introduced the dance to the people of
Bexhill, Sussex from 1804.[11]

It became fashionable in [Britain](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom")
during the [Regency period](/wiki/British_Regency "British Regency"), having
been made respectable by the endorsement of [Dorothea
Lieven](/wiki/Dorothea_Lieven "Dorothea Lieven"), wife of the Russian
ambassador.[12] Diarist [Thomas Raikes](/wiki/Thomas_Raikes_\(dandy\) "Thomas
Raikes \(dandy\)") later recounted that "No event ever produced so great a
sensation in English society as the introduction of the waltz in 1813".[13] In
the same year, a sardonic tribute to the dance by Lord Byron was anonymously
published (written the previous autumn).[14][15] Influential dance master and
author of instruction manuals, Thomas Wilson published _A Description of the
Correct Method of Waltzing_ in 1816.[16] [Almack's](/wiki/Almack%27s
"Almack's"), the most exclusive club in London, permitted the waltz though the
entry in the Oxford English Dictionary shows that it was considered "riotous
and indecent" as late as 1825. Ann Bronte in 'The Tenant of Wildfell Hall' has
a scene set in 1827 where the local vicar Reverend Milward tolerates
quadrilles and country dances but intervenes decisively when a waltz is called
for, declaring "No, no, I don't allow that! Come, it's time to be going
home".[17]

The waltz, and especially its closed position, became the example for the
creation of many other ballroom dances. Subsequently, new types of waltz have
developed, including many folk and several ballroom dances.

## Variants[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Waltz&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Variants")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Waltz_dance_pattern.png/250px-
Waltz_dance_pattern.png)](/wiki/File:Waltz_dance_pattern.png)

[](/wiki/File:Waltz_dance_pattern.png "Enlarge")

Waltz [rhythm].[18]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Jazz_waltz_dance_pattern.png/250px-
Jazz_waltz_dance_pattern.png)](/wiki/File:Jazz_waltz_dance_pattern.png)

[](/wiki/File:Jazz_waltz_dance_pattern.png "Enlarge")

[Jazz waltz](/wiki/Jazz_waltz "Jazz waltz") rhythm.[18]

In the 19th and early 20th century, numerous different waltz forms existed,
including versions performed in **3**  
**4** , **3**  
**8** or **6**  
**8** (sauteuse), and **5**  
**4** time (**5**  
**4** waltz, half and half).

In the 1910s, a form called the **" Hesitation Waltz"** was introduced by
[Vernon and Irene Castle](/wiki/Vernon_and_Irene_Castle "Vernon and Irene
Castle").[19] It incorporated "hesitations" and was danced to fast music. A
hesitation is basically a halt on the standing foot during the full waltz bar,
with the moving foot suspended in the air or slowly dragged. Similar figures
([Hesitation
Change](/w/index.php?title=Hesitation_Change&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hesitation
Change \(page does not exist\)"), [Drag
Hesitation](/w/index.php?title=Drag_Hesitation&action=edit&redlink=1 "Drag
Hesitation \(page does not exist\)"), and [Cross
Hesitation](/w/index.php?title=Cross_Hesitation&action=edit&redlink=1 "Cross
Hesitation \(page does not exist\)")) are incorporated in the [International
Standard](/wiki/International_Standard_\(dance\) "International Standard
\(dance\)") Waltz Syllabus.

The **Country Western Waltz** is mostly progressive, moving counter clock wise
around the dance floor. Both the posture and frame are relaxed, with posture
bordering on a slouch. The exaggerated hand and arm gestures of some ballroom
styles are not part of this style. Couples may frequently dance in the
[promenade position](/wiki/Promenade_position "Promenade position"), depending
on local preferences. Within Country Western waltz, there is the Spanish Waltz
and the more modern (for the late 1930s- early 1950s) Pursuit Waltz. At one
time it was considered ill treatment for a man to make the woman walk
backwards in some locations.[20]

In California the waltz was banned by Mission priests until after 1834 because
of the "closed" dance position.[21] Thereafter a Spanish Waltz was danced.
This Spanish Waltz was a combination of dancing around the room in closed
position, and a "formation" dance of two couples facing each other and
performing a sequence of steps.[21] "Valse a Trois Temps" was the "earliest"
waltz step, and the Rye Waltz was favoured as a couple dance.[22]

  * In contemporary [ballroom dance](/wiki/Ballroom_dance "Ballroom dance"), the fast versions of the waltz are called [Viennese Waltz](/wiki/Viennese_Waltz "Viennese Waltz") as opposed to the [Slow waltz](/wiki/Slow_waltz "Slow waltz").[23]
  * In [traditional Irish music](/wiki/Traditional_Irish_music "Traditional Irish music"), the waltz was taught by travelling dancing masters to those who could afford their lessons during the 19th century. By the end of that century, the dance spread to the middle and lower classes of Irish society and traditional triple-tune tunes and songs were altered to fit the waltz rhythm. During the 20th century, the waltz found a distinctively Irish playing style in the hands of [Céilidh](/wiki/C%C3%A9ilidh "Céilidh") musicians at [dances](/wiki/Ceili_dance "Ceili dance").[24][25]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/La_Valse%2C_Camille_Claudel.jpg/150px-
La_Valse%2C_Camille_Claudel.jpg)](/wiki/File:La_Valse,_Camille_Claudel.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:La_Valse,_Camille_Claudel.jpg "Enlarge")

Waltz, by [Camille Claudel](/wiki/Camille_Claudel "Camille Claudel") (1893)

  * [International Standard Waltz](/wiki/Waltz_\(International_Standard\) "Waltz \(International Standard\)") has only closed figures; that is, the couple never breaks the embrace.
  * The [American Style Waltz](/w/index.php?title=American_Style_Waltz&action=edit&redlink=1 "American Style Waltz \(page does not exist\)"), part of the [American Smooth](/wiki/American_Smooth "American Smooth") ballroom dance syllabus, in contrast to the [International Standard](/wiki/International_Standard_\(dance\) "International Standard \(dance\)") Waltz, involves breaking contact almost entirely in some figures. For example, the Syncopated Side-by-Side with Spin includes a free spin for both partners. Open rolls are another good example of an [open dance figure](/wiki/Ballroom_glossary#Open_dance_figure "Ballroom glossary"), in which the follower alternates between the lead's left and right sides, with the lead's left or right arm (alone) providing the lead. Waltzes were the staple of many American musicals and films, including "Waltz in Swing Time" sung by [Fred Astaire](/wiki/Fred_Astaire "Fred Astaire").
  * The [Scandinavian](/wiki/Scandinavia "Scandinavia") Waltz, performed as a part of [Scandinavian folk dance](/w/index.php?title=Scandinavian_folk_dance&action=edit&redlink=1 "Scandinavian folk dance \(page does not exist\)"), can be fast or slow, but the dancers are always rotating.
  * The [Peruvian Waltz](/wiki/Vals_\(Peruvian\) "Vals \(Peruvian\)") is called and recognised in Peru as _vals criollo_.
  * The [Mexican Waltz](/w/index.php?title=Mexican_Waltz&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mexican Waltz \(page does not exist\)") (_vals mexicano_) follows the same basic rhythmic pattern as the standard waltz, but the melodies reflect a strong Spanish influence. Mexico's [Juventino Rosas](/wiki/Juventino_Rosas "Juventino Rosas") wrote "[Sobre las Olas](/wiki/Sobre_las_Olas "Sobre las Olas")" or "Over the Waves", commonly known in the U.S. as a circus song played during a trapeze show.
  * The [Cajun Waltz](/w/index.php?title=Cajun_Waltz&action=edit&redlink=1 "Cajun Waltz \(page does not exist\)") is danced progressively around the floor, and is characterised by the subtle swaying of the hips and step very close to ordinary walking. It is danced entirely in the closed position.
  * The Cuban (or Tropical) Waltz follows the pattern of the standard waltz throughout the song.
  * The [Venezuelan waltz](/wiki/Venezuelan_waltz "Venezuelan waltz") provided a basis for distinctive regional musical composition.
  * The Contra Waltz (Freeform Waltz), included in most [contra dance](/wiki/Contra_dance "Contra dance") evenings, uses both open and closed positions, and incorporates moves from other dances such as [swing](/wiki/Swing_\(dance\) "Swing \(dance\)"), [modern jive](/wiki/Modern_jive "Modern jive") and [salsa](/wiki/Salsa_\(dance\) "Salsa \(dance\)"). Basically the dancers progress around the dance floor with a waltz step, but with no constraints on what moves they can use.
  * The [Valse Musette](/wiki/Bal-musette "Bal-musette"), a form of waltz popular in France, started in the late 19th century.
  * The [cross-step waltz](/wiki/Cross-step_waltz "Cross-step waltz") (French Valse Boston) developed in France in the early 20th century and is popular in social waltz groups today.
  * In folk dance from the [Alsace](/wiki/Alsace "Alsace") region, waltzes in odd metres such as **5**  
**4** , **8**  
**4** and **11**  
**4** are found. In modern [bal folk](/wiki/Bal_folk "Bal folk"), waltzes in
even higher metres are played and danced.

  * [Estonian](/wiki/Estonia "Estonia") folk dance [Labajalavalss](/w/index.php?title=Labajalavalss&action=edit&redlink=1 "Labajalavalss \(page does not exist\)") (flat of the foot waltz) performed in **3**  
**4** time.

Today both the faster Viennese Waltz, made forever popular by the Strauss
family, and the slower American and International style waltzes are extremely
popular with dancers of all ages.

  * [Sama'i](/wiki/Sama%27i "Sama'i") (also known as usul semai) is a vocal piece of Ottoman Turkish music composed in 6/8 metres. This form and metre (usul in Turkish) is often confused with the completely different Saz Semaisi, an instrumental form consisting of three to four sections, in 10/8 metre, or usul aksak semai (broken semai in Turkish). Semai is one of the most important forms in Ottoman Turkish Sufi music.[26][27]
  * The **Tsamikos** ([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): Τσάμικος, _Tsamikos_) or **Kleftikos** ([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): Κλέφτικος) is a popular traditional [folk dance](/wiki/Folk_dance "Folk dance") of [Greece](/wiki/Greece "Greece"), done to music of [3/4](/wiki/Triple_metre "Triple metre") metre.[28]
